awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Layered Multi-functional Building Panel for Energy Efficient, Affordable Housing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a building panel construction platform to create energy-efficient and affordable housing solutions. The platform integrates dissimilar materials into new functional materials using an automated single-step manufacturing method.  By collapsing multiple base materials and multiple envelope functions into a new building panel product, significant efficiencies are realized, creating a building product that is faster to assemble, greatly reducing labor costs, while optimizing dissimilar material attributes.  The multi-functional platform may meet the needs of a wide range of construction market segments, including single-family residential, low-rise multi-family, and most significantly, the growing mid-rise market. The same platform also may be applied in the building renovation segment as an energy-efficient façade panel.  The automated manufacturing method is industrialized in nature and may be scaled to produce high volumes of materials at speed.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel building panel construction platform.  The platform is a layered multi-functional, lightweight structural building panel manufactured from dissimilar materials in a continuous flow process. The range of layering materials may include — but is not limited to — sheets of wood veneer, wood composite panels, agricultural composite based panels, wood plastic composite panels, magnesium cement panels, gypsum panels, other mineral boned fiber composite panels, metalized films, polyurethane foams, biobased foams, and other functional layers. The platform may be configured to address a wide range of climatic load conditions.  The goal is for the building material to meet all the performance requirements of a modern envelope. This results in the exterior facades, structural elements, and interior elements most often being assembled on-site. The array of building materials often makes the construction process costly, cumbersome, and laced with inefficiencies. The proposed development may alter the current construction paradigm.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Housing in America is at a crossroads.  The need for affordable housing is growing exponentially, and the need for new affordable housing solutions that cross socio-economic boundaries has never been more pressing. One interview taught us the sheer scale of the issue, we learned by the year 2050, there will be a need for an equivalent of 429 new New York Cities in the world. This highlighted the need for our innovation, but also highlighted the need for high-capacity and high-velocity solutions, especially those materials with a lower carbon footprint. We need to look for bigger shifts, where dissimilar materials can be integrated into new, functional materials in a simple, single-step manufacturing process. Our layered multifunctional building panel can deliver the catalyst for that bigger shift.   

THE I-CORPS™ EXPERIENCE 

  • Allowed us to hear firsthand about market problems and needs, ultimately providing an understanding of the complex fragmentation that exists in the construction segment.
  • Gave us a clear picture of the entire market ecosystem, helping us to refine our customer segment more accurately and identify supply chain managers as our key customer.
  • Provided room to refine our solution, leading to a series of pivots, resulting in a far more sustainable product-market fit and value proposition.
  • Was a tremendous networking opportunity, with the potential for many new, unanticipated collaborations.
  • Left us with a new philosophy and commercialization methods that are now aligned with NRRI’s mission as an applied research institute. 

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, I-Corps™ encouraged us to put travel funding in reserve and provided a six-month no-cost extension to allow for live customer interviews. We interviewed 143 sector professionals, with 23 live interviews, across 11 stakeholder categories. We attended three virtual trade show events and two live trade show events.

Our overarching discovery pivot was away from petroleum based materials and towards 100% natural biobased materials for all three panel layers, the structural framing, the envelope barriers, and the thermal resistance layers. We discovered renewed global interest in Scrimber technology, resulting in a major pivot away from laminated veneer lumber as our structural material of choice.   

 PIVOT SUMMARY

  1. Considered—but rejected—market segment pivot toward the commercial retrofit segment.
  2. Minor pivot towards 100% biobased insulation materials.
  3. Minor pivot towards 100% biobased resin saturated paper barrier films. 
  4. Major pivot towards Scrimber as the primary engineered wood structural material.
  5. Major pivot towards single-family housing and away from mid-rise construction as a market point-of-entry.

We significantly advanced the commercialization potential of our innovation with a post-interview referral to a Swiss-based timber engineering firm working in nearly the same direction. The Swiss firm is quickly advancing towards a North American business startup. The firm has agreed to play a significant role as the “industrial partner” in a potential NSF Partnership for Innovation Research Partners proposal. Refreshed scholarly literature searches yielded significant new “Scrimber Panel” developed by Chinese material scientist.

Our building panel concept alters the current construction paradigm by collapsing multiple materials and building envelope design functions into a single-panel product, created in a single pass process flow, thus providing an affordable and sustainable (attainable) alternative.  Broadly thinking, we believe this work makes the case for more aggressive agile R&D practices in the construction sector. 


Last Modified: 03/02/2022
Modified by: Patrick K Donahue

Housing in America is at a crossroads.  The need for affordable housing is growing exponentially, and the need for new affordable housing solutions that cross socio-economic boundaries has never been more pressing. One interview taught us the sheer scale of the issue, we learned by the year 2050, there will be a need for an equivalent of 429 new New York Cities in the world. Gave us a clear picture of the entire market ecosystem, helping us to refine our customer segment more accurately and identify supply chain managers as our key customer.

We discovered renewed global interest in Scrimber technology, resulting in a major pivot away from laminated veneer lumber as our structural material of choice.

Considered—but rejected—market segment pivot toward the commercial retrofit segment.
Minor pivot towards 100% biobased insulation materials.
Minor pivot towards 100% biobased resin saturated paper barrier films. 
Major pivot towards Scrimber as the primary engineered wood structural material.
Major pivot towards single-family housing and away from mid-rise construction as a market point-of-entry.


We significantly advanced the commercialization potential of our innovation with a post-interview referral to a Swiss-based timber engineering firm working in nearly the same direction. The Swiss firm is quickly advancing towards a North American business startup. Broadly thinking, we believe this work makes the case for more aggressive agile R&D practices in the construction sector.
